page.title: 01SANDLINGS N.E. OF WOODBRIDGE
page.content: The area extends from light sandy soil in the east to marshy ground by the R. Deben in the west. Modern irrigation methods on the former have made agriculture viable. (eg. carrots, potatoes and commercial freezing crops of peas and beans, P.Y.O. soft fruits and apples, some corn). Small stretches of conifers reduce erosion of top soil by high winds. A large American Air Base occupies much of this section, and is self-contained apart from housing, making approaching roads very busy. The marshes have been and are under cultivation, mainly sugar-beet and corn. Apart from the housing on the Air Base, local habitations are sparse. Local work is provided on the Air Base, and in farming and horticulture, much of the latter being seasonal work. Other workers travel to local towns for work
